props.name: 2079pastQuestions
props.heading: Nepal Engineering Council License Exam 2079 Chaitra
props.title: NEC License Exam 2079

subjects.name: Mathematics I
subjects.description: If you're going to limit your dreams, at least tend them to infinity.

subjects.name: Physics
subjects.description: The universe is under no obligation to make sense to you.

subjects.name: Computer Programming
subjects.description: The real threat is not that computers will begin to think like men, but that men will begin to think like computers.

subjects.name: Mathematics II
subjects.description: If you're going to limit your dreams, at least tend them to infinity.

subjects.name: Chemistry
subjects.description: If you're going to limit your dreams, at least tend them to infinity.

subjects.name: Basic Mechanical Engineering
subjects.description: If you're going to limit your dreams, at least tend them to infinity.

subjects.name: Electro Engineering Materials
subjects.description: If you're going to limit your dreams, at least tend them to infinity.

subjects.name: Computer Systems & Database Concepts
subjects.description: If you're going to limit your dreams, at least tend them to infinity.
Computers have lots of memory but no imagination.

subjects.name: Digital Electronics
subjects.description: If you're going to limit your dreams, at least tend them to infinity.

pass: Wow, you passed! Are you sure you're not cheating?
I'd be impressed if you weren't such a sore winner. Just kidding, congrats!
I'll let you have this win as long as you promise to buy me a drink.
You must have cheated because there's no way you passed fairly.
You're welcome for the pity points
fail: Oopsie daisy, looks like you missed the mark
A for effort, F for execution
I think the universe is telling you to stick to your day job
Looks like your crystal ball needs a polish
That was almost impressive, in a not-at-all impressive kind of way.
Looks like you're not quite ready for the big leagues yet
Well, that didn't go as planned
Uh-oh, you'll have to try again
You're doing great... if your goal is to fail
I'm not saying you're bad, but...
This quiz was just a warm-up, right?
Let's hope you don't loose sleep over this one.
You're not bad... you're just not good enough.
Don't worry, it's just a quiz... or is it?
Not quite the result we were hoping for!

faq.question: What is the source for the content of the quizzes?
faq.answer: The content of the quizzes included in this site is based on the input and recollection of individuals who have taken the exam.

faq.question: Is the authenticity of the quizzes verified?
How can I contribute?
faq.answer: If you are someone who's appeared in the license exam, you can help by posting questions. See contact information at the bottom of this page.

setA.name: What are paracrine enzymes used for?
options: Regulation of gene expression in a single cell
setA.hint: Paracrine enzymes are signaling molecules that are secreted by cells to act on nearby cells, usually within the same tissue or organ.

setA.name: Which of the following amino acids does not posses charge?
setA.hint: Glycine is a non-polar amino acid, meaning that it has a neutral charge and is not attracted to charged molecules. In contrast, Arginine, Lysine, and Histidine are polar amino acids that possess a positive charge at physiological pH.

setA.name: Which of the following cannot be considered a neuroglial cell?
setA.hint: Satellite cells are not considered neurological cells because they are not neurons or glial cells, which are the two main types of cells found in the nervous system. Instead, satellite cells are a type of muscle cell that is involved in muscle regeneration and repair.

setA.name: Which equation is used to calculate cardiac output?
setA.hint: CO = Heart rate (HR) x Stroke volume (SV)

setA.name: Select the correct statement about the ureters.
options: Ureters contain sphincters at the entrance to the bladder to prevent the backflow of urine.
The epithelium is stratified squamous, which allows a great deal of stretch
The ureter is innervated by parasympathetic nerve endings only
The ureters are capable of peristalsis like that of the gastrointestinal tract.

setA.name: Which of the following terms best describes the mechanical deformation that occurs when a viscoelastic object is suddenly subjected to a constant stress?
setA.hint: The mechanical deformation that occurs when a viscoelastic object is suddenly subjected to constant stress is called stress relaxation. Hysteresis, creep, and fatigue are other types of mechanical deformation that can occur in viscoelastic materials, but they are not specifically related to sudden application of a constant stress.

setA.name: What aspect of the liver is difficult to replicate in the manufacturing of an artificial liver?
setA.hint: The density of hepatocytes, the main functional cells of the liver, is much higher than can be achieved in most in vitro systems . This is because the cells in the liver are packed tightly together in hepatic plates, which allows for efficient exchange of materials and metabolic waste products.

setA.name: Which of the following implant metals is most commonly used for orthopedic applications?
setA.hint: Titanium is a popular choice for orthopedic implants due to its unique combination of properties that make it well-suited for this application.

setA.name: Which of the following aspects of synthetic polymers cannot be replicated by natural polymers?
setA.hint: Both thermal stability and molecular weight distribution can be correct answers to this question, depending on the context. Natural polymers such often have a broader range of molecular weights and less precise molecular weight distribution compared to synthetic polymers. Thermal stability refers to the ability of a polymer to maintain its structure and properties when exposed to high temperatures. But at normal temperatures, the difference in  thermal stability of synthetic and natural polymer's isn't significant which makes molecular weight distribution more appropriate.

setA.name: Which of the following element is utilized in the heat vulcanization process of rubber?
setA.hint: The element utilized in the heat vulcanization process of rubber is sulfur. When sulfur is added to natural rubber and heated, it cross-links the polymer chains, making the rubber more durable and resistant to heat and wear.

setA.name: What is the term for the surface on which an enzyme is immobilized within a matrix?
setA.hint: The support matrix is typically a three-dimensional network of polymers or other materials that provide a scaffold for the immobilization of enzymes.

setA.name: In the statement "Phagocytes won't eat the pathogens unless the pathogens are nicely buttered for them",  the term 'buttered' is concerned with which of the following?
setA.hint: The term 'nicely buttered' in the statement is an analogy that describes the process of opsonization, where the coating of the pathogen with opsonins (e.g., antibodies or complement proteins) is analogous to spreading butter on bread to make it more attractive and easier to eat.

setA.name: A tilting heart valve has ___ and ___ components.
setA.hint: The circular frame of a tilting heart valve is typically made of a biocompatible metal such as titanium or stainless steel and the tilting disc is made of polymer such as pyrolytic carbon.

setA.name: Which of the following is a feature of modern total hip replacements?
setA.hint: Modular is a feature of modern total hip replacement (THR) implants. Modular THRs are made up of separate components that can be mixed and matched to better fit a patient's individual anatomy. Fixed, integrated, and flexible are not typically used to describe modern THR implants, as they do not accurately reflect the current state of THR technology.

setA.name: Which of the following is used to guide a catheter for minimally invasive surgery?
setA.hint: All of these tools can be used to guide a catheter during minimally invasive surgery, but a guide wire is specifically designed to help navigate a catheter to the target location. Endoscopes, sheaths, and probes can provide visual guidance and access to the surgical site, but a guide wire is necessary to direct the catheter through complex or tortuous anatomy.

setA.name: Which of the following categories of biological skin makes use of porcine skin to treat burns?
setA.hint: Xenografts involve using tissue from a different species, and in some cases, porcine skin can be used as a temporary covering for severe burns until the patient's own skin can be harvested for an autograft. Amniotic membrane grafts and allografts both involve using human tissue, with amniotic membranes typically being obtained from placental tissue and allografts coming from a donor of the same species. Autografts involve using a patient's own skin to cover a wound or burned area.

setA.name: Which of the following is a characteristic exhibited by intraocular lenses?
options: They are in close integration with the tissues that surround it.
They are only suitable for temporary use.
They are made of smooth biomaterials such as glass.
They are used to replace the natural lenses of the eye after a cataract surgery.
setA.hint: Intraocular lenses (IOLs) are implanted in the eye after the removal of a cataract. IOLs are not designed to integrate with tissues that surround them as this can obstruct visibility. Additionally, IOLs are not only suitable for temporary use, as they are designed to be a long-term replacement for the natural lens. Finally, IOLs are not typically made of glass, but rather are made of materials such as silicone or acrylic.

setA.name: If a tissue is able to repair itself, then such approach is known as
setA.hint: Regenerative approach is a field of tissue engineering that focuses on harnessing the body's own regenerative capabilities to repair or replace damaged tissue. This can involve using stem cells, growth factors, or other biomaterials to stimulate the body's natural healing processes and promote tissue regeneration.

setA.name: What will be the affect of increasing the number of electrons emitted from the cathode to the anode in an X-ray tube?
options: The wavelength of the X-rays produced will decrease.
The intensity of the X-rays produced will increase.
The duration of X-ray exposure will decrease.
The penetration power of the X-ray produced will increase
setA.hint: Increasing the number of electrons emitted from the cathode to the anode in an X-ray tube will increase the intensity of the X-rays produced. This is because the number of electrons reaching the anode and interacting with the target material will increase, leading to a greater number of X-rays being produced.

setA.name: Which of the following is a feature of second generation CT scanners?
setA.hint: Second generation CT scanners can image head and body. The scan time of second generation CT scanners is typically longer than 5 minutes and pencil beam is a feature of first generation CT scanners.

setA.name: Which of the following can be increased to improve the SNR in an MRI?
setA.hint: The gradient strength can be increased to improve the SNR in an MRI. Repetition time, flip angle, and echo time may affect image contrast and resolution, but they do not directly impact the SNR. Repetition time determines the time between consecutive excitation pulses, flip angle controls the degree of magnetization flip and echo time determines the time between excitation pulse and the detection of the MRI signal.

setA.name: Which of the following is not a biological effect of ultrasound?
setA.hint: Ultrasound is a type of mechanical wave that propagates through a medium and not an electromagnetic wave.

setA.name: What is the number of gray shades that appear in a radiograph called?
setA.hint: The number of gray shades that appear in a radiograph is called dynamic range. Spatial resolution refers to the ability to distinguish between small structures in an image, such as tiny features or details. Contrast, on the other hand, refers to the difference in brightness or density between different areas of an image. Spatial frequency is a measure of the number of cycles of a repeating pattern that are present in a given unit of space.

setA.name: Which of the following is a feature of PET and SPECT?
options: They do not require imaging dyes
Can be used to visualize metabolic functions
Do not involve exposure to ionizing radiation
Can be used to produce more detailed image
setA.hint: PET and SPECT can be used to visualize metabolic functions such as glucose uptake, blood flow, and neurotransmitter activity.

setA.name: Which of the following physiological variables may be measured with a thermistor?
setA.hint: A thermistor can measure changes in temperature that occur with each breath, allowing for the calculation of respiration rate in a non-invasive fashion and can be easily performed in a clinical setting.

setA.name: Monitor which is placed at the bedside for monitoring cardiac functions of a patient is known as
setA.hint: Cardiac monitor is specifically designed to measure and display information related to heart's activity.

setA.name: A pacemaker and a cell phone may communicate via.
setA.hint: Bluetooth technology allows wireless communication between electronic devices over short distances, making it a suitable method for communication between a pacemaker and a cell phone.

setA.name: If total oxygen content in artery is 150 ml/L and mixed venous concentration of oxygen is 110 ml/L and the amount of absorbed oxygen in 280 ml/min, what will be the cardiac output?
setA.hint: Fick's principle: CO = (Oxygen consumption) / (Arterial oxygen content - Venous oxygen content)

setA.name: The centrifugal force of a centrifuge depends upon angular velocity and which of the following?
options: Mass of the object being centrifuged.
setA.hint: The magnitude of the centrifugal force is directly proportional to the square of the angular velocity and the radius of the rotor.

setA.name: What is the normal intesity range used in pure tone audiometers?
setA.hint: Pure tone audiometers typically use a normal intensity range of 0 dB to 100 dB.

setA.name: Cardioverter differs from pacemakers in which of the following aspects?
options: Cardioverters are larger in size than pacemakers.
Cardioverter are implanted in the chest, while pacemakers are worn externally.
Pacemakers provide a smaller electrical impulse than cardioverters.
Cardioverters are powered by a battery, while pacemakers are powered by body heat.
setA.hint: Cardioverters differ from pacemakers in that they provide a larger electrical impulse than pacemakers. Cardioverters are used to convert abnormal heart rhythms back to a normal rhythm, while pacemakers are used to regulate the heart rate and rhythm by sending small electrical impulses to the heart

setA.name: Which of the following compounds absorbs maximum CO\(_2\) laser?
setA.hint: Out of the given options, water is the most effective absorber of CO2 laser, followed by melanin and blood. Bone is a poor absorber of CO2 laser, which makes it less suitable for laser surgery.

setA.name: Among the following options, which has the ability to heat the largest tissue surface area?
setA.hint: Shortwave diathermy uses high-frequency electromagnetic energy to generate heat deep inside the body, which can effectively treat a large area of tissue at once. This is achieved by using large applicator heads or multiple applicator heads, which can cover a large surface area. In contrast, plug-in heat packs and thermal ultrasound are typically used for localized heating of smaller areas.

setA.name: Which of the following kind of membranes does modern dialyzers use?
setA.hint: Modern dialyzers typically use hollow fiber membranes.

setA.name: In case of oxygen failure in an anesthesia machine, the oxygen valve is blocked to prevent the back flow of which of the following?
setA.hint: In the event of oxygen failure in an anesthesia machine, the oxygen valve is blocked to prevent the back flow of nitrous oxide. This is because nitrous oxide is typically used as an anesthetic gas in combination with oxygen. If the oxygen supply were to fail, there would be a risk of hypoxia (oxygen deprivation) if nitrous oxide continued to flow. By blocking the oxygen valve, the anesthesia machine prevents the backflow of nitrous oxide into the oxygen supply line, reducing the risk of hypoxia.

setA.name: Which of the following safety measures can be taken for patient safety regarding leakage current?
options: Reducing the ground resistance to zero
Exposing the equipment to strong electromagnetic fields
setA.hint: Reducing the ground resistance to zero or exposing the equipment to strong electromagnetic fields is not a safe measure and can actually increase the risk of electrical shock. And although, changing the entire equipment is correct it isn't exactly economical so increasing the insulation is the most appropriate answer.

setA.name: The knee voltage of a germanium diode is
setA.hint: The knee voltage of a germanium diode is approximately 0.3 volts and that of silicone diode is 0.7 volts.

setA.name: What does Colpitt's oscillator use for signal generation?
setA.hint: Colpitt's oscillator is a type of LC oscillator that employs an LC resonant tank circuit to produce a sinusoidal waveform.

setA.name: In which of the following applications are 3-phase 4 wire systems used?
setA.hint: 3-phase 4 wire systems can be used in both primary and secondary distribution applications, depending on the specific requirements of the system. However, they are more commonly used in secondary distribution. Primary transmission and secondary transmission systems typically use higher voltage levels and different configurations, such as 3-phase 3 wire or 1-phase 2 wire, depending on the specific application.

setA.name: A zener diode is commonly used as a
setA.hint: A zener diode is a special type of diode that is designed to operate in the reverse breakdown region of the diode's characteristic curve. When the reverse voltage applied to the zener diode exceeds the zener voltage, the diode starts conducting and maintains a nearly constant voltage drop across its terminals. This property of the zener diode makes it useful as a voltage regulator in electronic circuits to provide a constant DC voltage output even when the input voltage varies.

setA.name: If a 100 Coulombs charge flows through a conductor for 2 seconds, then the magnitude of current produced in the conductor is equal to
setA.hint: Current (A) = Charge (C) / Time (S)

setA.name: Two generators are connected in parallel for
setA.hint: Two generators are typically connected in parallel to supply power to large AC loads. This is because large AC loads require high power, and a single generator may not be able to meet the demand alone. By connecting multiple generators in parallel, their power outputs are combined, increasing the overall power capacity of the system. In this way, the generators can work together to supply the large AC loads with the necessary power. It cannot be large DC loads because DC loads are supplied by batterires or inverters not generators.

setA.name: Identify the universal logic gate from the following options.
setA.hint: NAND is a universal gate. AND and OR are basic logic gates and XOR is a derived gate.

setA.name: How many select lines are there in an 8 to 1 MUX?
setA.hint: In a Multiplexer (MUX), the number of select lines determines the number of input lines and output lines. In an 8-to-1 MUX, there are eight input lines and one output line. The three select lines determine which of the eight input lines is connected to the output line.

setA.name: What is a JK flip flop used to realize when J=K?
setA.hint: When J=K=0, the output state of a JK flip-flop does not change and what J=K=1, the output state is reversed. Effectively, creating a toggle function like the T flip-flop does.

setA.name: Which of the following statements is true about PROM?
options: PROM can be programmed unlimited number of times.
Programming a PROM requires UV radiation.
PROM can only be programmed by the user once.
PROM is programmed at the time of manufacture.
setA.hint: PROM stands for Programmable Read-Only Memory and is manufactured in an empty state and then programmed later using a PROM programmer.

setA.name: What is a transmission without a start bit, a stop bit or a parity bit in serial communication called?
setA.hint: In serial communication, continuous transmission refers to a method of transmitting data where there are no start or stop bits, and no parity bit. Instead, data is sent continuously, with each bit being immediately followed by the next bit. This method of transmission is often used for high-speed data transfer and is more efficient than other methods that require start and stop bits.

setA.name: What is another term that can be used for band stop filter?
setA.hint: Snubber is used to supress voltage spikes in electrical circuits. A band select or a low pass filter allows frequencies of a range to pass through while attenuating others. A band stop or a notch filter attenuates frequencies of a range while allows others to pass.

setA.name: How can the location of poles be adjusted to improve the transient response of a control system?
options: By moving poles closer to the imaginary axis
By moving poles farther from the imaginary axis
By moving poles towards the right half of the complex plane
By moving poles towards the origin
setA.hint: To improve the transient response of a control system, the location of poles should be adjusted. Moving the poles closer to the imaginary axis helps in reducing the settling time and overshoot, resulting in a faster and more stable response. This is typically achieved by modifying the controller or system parameters to adjust the pole positions.

setA.name: In a parallel RLC circuit, the electrical voltage (E) is analogous to which of the following component in a mechanical system?
setA.hint: The electrical voltage in a parallel RLC circuit and the force in a mechanical system are analogous because they both represent the driving factors that cause the system to operate.

setA.name: The output of a system represented by the transfer function \( \displaystyle \frac{1}{1+\omega^2} \) is
setA.hint: The transfer function of the system is 1/(1 + ω^2). This is a second-order system with a single pole at ω = j and no zeros.

setA.name: The nature of a parabolic antenna's transmission line is
setA.hint: The transmission line of a parabolic antenna is a type of coaxial cable that connects the antenna to the receiver or transmitter. The transmission line is typically unidirectional, meaning that it carries signals in one direction only, from the transmitter to the antenna or from the antenna to the receiver.

setA.name: The maximum efficiency of an AM wave is
setA.hint: In AM (Amplitude Modulation) wave, the amplitude of the carrier wave is varied in proportion to the instantaneous amplitude of the modulating signal (message signal) to transmit information. The modulating signal carries the information, but it also results in the carrier wave's power getting wasted in transmitting the sidebands. As a result, the maximum efficiency of an AM wave is limited to one-third or 33.33%.

setA.name: Which of the following transforms a continuous time signal into a discrete time signal?
setA.hint: Sampling is a process where the continuous time signal is measured or "sampled" at a fixed rate or interval, resulting in a sequence of discrete values. Filtering, quantization, and encoding are subsequent processes that are typically performed on the sampled signal to reduce noise, improve accuracy, and compress the data for storage or transmission.

setA.name: Which of the following in an enlarging scale?
setA.hint: A X:Y scale means that Y is the actual measurements of an object and X is the measurement used to represent it. So if the actual measurement of an object is 1 unit then 5:1 means that the object appears five times larger than its original size in the sheet, which makes 5:1 the enlarging scale. 1:10, 1:100, 1:5 are reducing scales.

setA.name: If the annual worth of a project is 9000 at a 10% discount rate, what will be it's capitalized value?
setA.hint: Capitalized Value = Annual Worth / Discount Rate

setA.name: A chart showing the key events within the duration of a project is called
setA.hint: A chart showing the key events within the duration of a project is called a milestone chart. It is a graphical representation that illustrates the significant events or milestones of a project in chronological order.

setA.name: Which of the following risks is beyond a firm's control?
setA.hint: Market risks are beyond a firm's control. These risks are caused by external factors such as changes in the economy, political instability, and shifts in consumer preferences or behavior

setA.name: Which of the following is a key component of professional ethics in engineering?
setA.hint: Honesty and integrity are key components of professional ethics in engineering because they form the foundation for responsible and ethical behavior. Engineers are expected to act honestly, truthfully, and with integrity in their professional practices.

setA.name: The tenure of members of Nepal Engineering Council is
setA.hint: The tenure of members of NEC is 4 years.

setB.name: Ornithine cycle is recognized for formation of which of the following compounds?
setB.hint: The ornithine cycle, also known as the urea cycle, is a metabolic pathway in which nitrogenous waste, in the form of ammonia, is converted into urea for excretion from the body. This cycle takes place primarily in the liver and involves a series of biochemical reactions that ultimately result in the conversion of ammonia to urea.

setB.name: The 40nm gap when a new bone is being formed is filled with
setB.hint: The 40nm gap during new bone formation is filled with Ca\(^{2+}\) ions to form hydroxyapatite crystals, which are the mineral component of bone tissue. These crystals provide the bone with its strength and rigidity.

setB.name: The contact angle associated with water for a hydrophobic material is
setB.hint: The contact angle is the angle at which a liquid meets a solid surface. In the case of a hydrophobic material (one that repels water), the contact angle of water on the surface of the material is greater than 90 degrees, and typically around 120 degrees

setB.name: What does the following picture represent?
Which biomaterial amongst the following is best suited for craniomaxillofacial reconstruction implants?
setB.hint: Ceramics are best suited for cranio-maxillary implants due to their biocompatibility, durability, and ability to mimic the properties of natural bone.

setB.name: Which of the following biomaterials is used in IOL?
setB.hint: PMMA and silicone are the most commonly used materials for intraocular lenses (IOLs), with PMMA being used more frequently in developing countries.

setB.name: Which of the following factors influence slice thickness?
options: Slice-select gradient slope and transmit bandwidth
setB.hint: The slice-select gradient slope determines the spatial extent of the slice and is responsible for selecting a specific slice location. The amplitude and duration of the gradient affect the slice thickness. The transmit bandwidth determines the range of frequencies that are excited by the radio frequency (RF) pulse, which can affect the slice thickness. A larger transmit bandwidth can result in a thicker slice. Phase encoding slope is a factor that determines the spatial resolution in the phase-encoding direction, but it does not directly influence the slice thickness.

setB.name: Which of the following radio isotopes does not emit positron?
setB.hint: Isotopes which undergo this decay and thereby emit positrons include: oxygen-15, fluorine-18, rubidium-82, carbon-11 but not carbon-14.

setB.name: If the anatomical dead space is 150 ml, the respiration rate is 12 cycles per minute, and the tidal volume is 500 ml, then the aerobic ventilation must be
setB.hint: Effective ventilation = (Tidal volume - Dead space) x Respiratory rate

setB.name: What is the measurement range of an EMG wave?
setB.hint: The electrical activity is measured in microvolts (μV) and represents the motor unit activity of the muscle. The typical range of EMG amplitude for resting muscle is 0-100 μV.

setB.name: The SA node is called the natural pacemaker of the heart because
options: It initiates the heartbeat and sets the rhythm
It has very high sympathetic innervations
It is located in the left ventricle
It is made of natural fibers
setB.hint: The SA (sinoatrial) node is called the natural pacemaker of the heart because it initiates the heartbeat and sets the rhythm of the heart. It is located in the right atrium of the heart and is responsible for generating the electrical impulses that stimulate the heart to contract and pump blood throughout the body.

setB.name: If the AV node fails to produce impulses, which of the following widens in an ECG reading?
setB.hint: The P wave represents atrial depolarization and the T wave represents ventricular repolarization, so they are not directly affected by the AV node. The QRS complex represents ventricular depolarization and is affected by the delay or blockage of impulses from the AV node to the ventricles. Therefore, if the AV node fails to produce impulses, the duration of the QRS complex will widen.

setB.name: For best operation of BJT, which region must the operating point be set at?
setB.hint: In the active region, the transistor operates as an amplifier, and the output signal faithfully reproduces the input signal. In this region, both the base-emitter junction and the collector-base junction are forward-biased, and the transistor is able to amplify small signals with high linearity.

setB.name: The resistivity of a dynamic diode is dependent on
options: The direction of the applied voltage
The thickness of the depletion region
setB.hint: The resistivity of a dynamic diode is dependent on the thickness of the depletion region. The depletion region is the region where there are no mobile charge carriers due to the introduction of impurities into the diode material.

setB.name: Which of the following represents the nature of a circuit in the diagram below?
setB.hint: The above figure represents an active low pass filter.

setB.name: Which of the following can be used to realize an XOR gate?
setB.hint: An XOR (exclusive OR) gate can be realized using a combination of AND, OR, and NOT gates. One possible way to implement an XOR gate is by using two input signals (A and B) and combining them with two AND gates, then combining the outputs of the AND gates with an OR gate, and finally inverting the output of the OR gate with a NOT gate.

setB.name: The overall transfer function from block digram reduction for cascaded blocks is
setB.hint: Gain of block get multiplied when they are cascaded where cascaded means that the blocks are in series combination with no summer in between.

setB.name: Find the Nyquist frequency for \( x(t) = 5 \cos(200\pi t) + 5 \cos(300\pi t) + 5 \cos(400\pi t)+ 5 \cos(500\pi t) \).
setB.hint: The sampling frequency should be greater than or equal to twice the bandwidth of the signal.

setB.name: What is the maximum intake of students engineering colleges in Nepal as per NEC Act 2078?
setB.hint: Honestly who cares.

setB.name: How does engineering differ from pure science?
options: Engineering focuses on theoretical research, while pure science is more practical.
Engineering applies scientific principles to design and create useful products and systems.
Engineering is primarily concerned with environmental preservation, while pure science focuses on exploration
Engineering only involves building physical structures, while pure science deals with abstract concepts.
setB.hint: While both engineering and pure science involve the application of scientific knowledge, they differ in their objectives and approaches. Engineering utilizes scientific principles to develop practical solutions and create useful products, systems, and technologies. It focuses on the design, construction, and implementation of solutions to real-world problems. In contrast, pure science is more concerned with the pursuit of knowledge and understanding fundamental scientific concepts through observation, experimentation, and theoretical research. Pure science aims to expand scientific knowledge without necessarily having direct practical applications in mind.

setA.name: Agglutination reaction is more sensitive than percipitation for the detection of ___.
setA.hint: Agglutination and precipitation reactions are both commonly used in immunology for the detection and identification of antigens and antibodies. In an agglutination reaction, small particles, such as latex beads or red blood cells, are coated with either antigens or antibodies. When the specific antigen or antibody is present in a sample, it will bind to the corresponding antibody or antigen-coated particles, resulting in visible clumping or agglutination. Agglutination can be observed macroscopically or microscopically.

setA.name: Haemopoiesis is a process of the production of ___.
setA.hint: Haemopoiesis, also known as hematopoiesis, is the process by which new blood cells are formed. It occurs primarily in the bone marrow, specifically in the red bone marrow found in the spongy portions of certain bones.

setA.name: The corpus callosum is a ___.
options: Nerual pathway that connects the right and left hemispheres
setA.hint: The corpus callosum is a prominent structure in the brain that serves as the main pathway for communication between the two cerebral hemispheres.

setA.name: Which is true of the pulmonary circuit?
options: Blood oxygen content is higher in the pulmonary vein than in the pulmonary artery
Blood is pumped through it by the left ventricle
Resting blood pressure in the pulmonary artery is normally equal to that in the aorta
The cardiac output into the pulmonary circuit is approximately 1/6 of that into the systemic circuit.
setA.hint: In the pulmonary circuit, deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle is pumped into the pulmonary arteries to reach the lungs for oxygenation. After oxygenation, the blood returns to the heart through the pulmonary veins, and at this point, its oxygen content is higher.

setA.name: When  substances move from the tubule into the surrounding afferent ateriole, this is known as ___.
setA.hint: When substances move from the tubule into the surrounding afferent arteriole, this process is known as tubular secretion.

setA.name: The greatest source of elasticity in human skeletal muscle tissue is attributed to ___.
setA.hint: The greatest source of elasticity in human skeletal muscle tissue is attributed to the parallel elastic component. It includes structures such as the epimysium, perimysium, and endomysium. The series elastic component refers to the tendons and other structures that transmit the force generated by the muscle to the bones. It does not contribute significantly to muscle elasticity, nor do the continuous elastic component and active elastic components.

setA.name: Any material that once placed in the human body has minimal interaction with its  surrounding tissue is called as ___.
setA.hint: Bioinert materials are substances that exhibit minimal interaction with the surrounding tissue once placed in the human body. These materials are designed to have high chemical stability and low reactivity, allowing them to remain largely unchanged and non-reactive in the biological environment. Biomaterials is a broader term encompassing all types of materials used in medical and biological applications, including both bioinert and bioactive materials.

setA.name: Collagen is best described as a ___.
setA.hint: Collagen is best described as a fibrous structural protein that provides strength, support, and flexibility to various tissues in the body. Collagen is composed of three polypeptide chains called alpha chains, which are tightly coiled together to form a triple helix structure. Therefore, d) is the most appropriate answer.

setA.name: ___ is to obtain a smooth surface that stimulates natural tooth surface.
setA.hint: Glazing is a dental process that involves applying a layer of ceramic material onto a dental restoration, such as a crown or a veneer, to obtain a smooth and polished surface.

setA.name: The incorporation of which of the following peptide sequences, during surface  modification, has been shown to specifically increase the attachment of neural cells?
setA.hint: The peptide sequences YIGSR (Tyr-Ile-Gly-Ser-Arg) and IKVAV (Ile-Lys-Val-Ala-Val) have been shown to specifically increase the attachment of neural cells during surface modification.

setA.name: In which of the technique enzyme and polymer are bridged by the use of bi-functional reagent?
setA.hint: In the technique of covalent cross-linking, enzymes and polymers are bridged by the use of a bi-functional reagent. The bi-functional reagent contains two functional groups, one that can react with the enzyme and another that can react with the polymer. During the covalent cross-linking process, the first functional group of the bi-functional reagent reacts with specific amino acid residues on the enzyme, forming a covalent bond between the enzyme and the reagent. The second functional group of the reagent then reacts with the polymer, creating a covalent bond between the enzyme and the polymer matrix.

setA.name: Von Willebrand factor is synthesized by ECs and secreted into sub endothelial matrix,  where it is bound by which of the following?
setA.hint: Once secreted, vWF binds to specific types of collagen present in the subendothelial matrix. These collagen types are collagen I, III, IV, and V.

setA.name: Which of the following is not an ideal indication for a bioprosthetic valve (compared to a  mechanical prosthetic valve)?
setA.hint: A young adult male may not be an ideal candidate for a bioprosthetic valve due to the relatively shorter durability of bioprosthetic valves compared to mechanical valves. Younger patients typically have a longer life expectancy and may require valve replacement surgery in the future if a bioprosthetic valve wears out or degenerates.

setA.name: What is the disadvantage of ceramic bearings in THR?
setA.hint: Despite their excellent wear resistance, ceramic bearings may experience a phenomenon called "third-body wear." This occurs when particles, such as debris or fragments from the surrounding tissues or implant components, become trapped between the bearing surfaces and cause abrasive damage.

setA.name: Which is a complication associated particularly with a urethral catheter?
options: More likely to cause urinary tract infections and bladder stones
Difficult to site the catheter for overweight people
The catheter site may produce a discharge
Mechanical irritation to the urethra provokes an intense, acute, and chronic  inflammatory tissue response
setA.hint: Urethral catheters, when left in place for an extended period, can increase the risk of developing urinary tract infections (UTIs). The presence of a catheter provides a pathway for bacteria to enter the urinary tract, leading to infection. UTIs can cause symptoms such as frequent urination, urgency, pain or burning during urination, cloudy or bloody urine, and lower abdominal discomfort. Additionally, the use of urethral catheters can also contribute to the formation of bladder stones. The catheter can disrupt the normal flow of urine and cause stagnation, leading to the precipitation of mineral deposits and the formation of stones in the bladder.

setA.name: Which of the following is a limitation of using autologous fat as a biomaterial in plastic  surgery?
options: It is difficult to obtain in sufficient quantities
It is prone to resorption and volume loss over time
It is associated with a high risk of infection
setA.hint: One of the limitations of using autologous fat as a biomaterial in plastic surgery is its tendency to undergo resorption and volume loss over time. After fat grafting, a portion of the transferred fat may not establish a sufficient blood supply and can be reabsorbed by the body. This can result in a reduction in volume and may require additional grafting sessions to achieve the desired outcome.

setA.name: What is the region enclosed by the optical cavity called in a LASER machine?
setA.hint: An optical resonator refers to the space between the mirrors or reflective surfaces in a LASER machine. The optical resonator consists of two mirrors placed at opposite ends of the laser medium, which could be a solid, liquid, or gas. These mirrors are highly reflective, allowing the light to bounce back and forth between them multiple times. This bouncing of light within the resonator enhances the stimulated emission process and helps to generate a coherent and amplified beam of laser ligh

setA.name: Which one of the following statements best defines tissue engineering?
options: It is the replacement of tissues using techniques developed from a combination of  biology and engineering principles.
It is the growth of tissue components in vitro that can be used to regenerate diseased or damaged tissue.
It is the implantation of scaffolds for the in situ repair of diseased or damaged tissue.
It is a form of bioactive fixation.
setA.hint: While options a), c) and d), each describe one aspect of tissue engineering, they do not encopass the full concept of tissue engineering. Tissue engineering involves the application of principles from both biology and engineering to create functional tissue constructs that can replace or restore damaged or diseased tissues in the body. Therefore b) is the most appropriate answer.

setA.name: Which of the following is a characteristic of the photons produced by the bremsstrahlung  method?
options: They have a single discrete energy level
They have a continuous range of energy levels
They are absorbed by atoms in the target material
setA.hint: The bremsstrahlung method is a process in which photons are generated by the deceleration of charged particles, such as electrons, as they interact with the target material. In this process, the electrons experience acceleration or deceleration due to the electric field of the target atoms, emitting photons in the form of X-rays. Unlike characteristic X-rays, which have discrete energy levels specific to the target material, the photons produced by bremsstrahlung have a continuous range of energy levels.

setA.name: Which of the following is NOT true regarding dose in CT imaging?
options: Reducing slice thickness reduces patient dose.
Noise reduction often leads to an increased patient dose.
An obese patient requires an increased dose to produce an image with an acceptable  noise level.
Good quality control is necessary to ensure the patient dose is as low as possible.
setA.hint: Reducing slice thickness in CT imaging does not directly reduce patient dose. Slice thickness refers to the thickness of the imaging plane or section that is captured during a single rotation of the CT scanner. While reducing slice thickness can improve spatial resolution and image detail, it does not have a direct impact on patient dose. Therefore, the answer is a) Reducing slice thickness reduces patient dose.

setA.name: Increasing the magnetic field ___.
options: Reduces the risk of tissue heating.
Reduces the danger from metallic projectiles.
setA.hint: Increasing the magnetic field strength in MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) has several effects, including an increase in the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR). The SNR is a measure of the strength of the signal relative to the background noise in the image. By increasing the magnetic field strength, the signal produced by the protons in the body is enhanced, resulting in a higher SNR. This leads to improved image quality and better visualization of anatomical structures. a) Susceptibility artifacts are distortions or signal voids in the MRI image caused by magnetic field inhomogeneities, such as those arising from air-tissue interfaces or metallic objects. Increasing the magnetic field strength can exacerbate susceptibility artifacts rather than reduce them.

setA.name: Arrange from fastest to slowest according to penetration of ultrasound.
options: Lung, fat, soft tissue, liver, blood, muscle, tendons, bone
Bone, tendons, muscles, blood, liver, fat, soft tissue, lung
Bone, tendons, muscles, blood, liver, soft tissue, fat, lung
Bone, Muscles, tendons, blood, liver, soft tissue, fat, lung
setA.hint: Ultrasound waves penetrate different tissues at different speeds based on their acoustic properties. In general, denser and more solid tissues tend to slow down or attenuate ultrasound waves more than less dense and more fluid-like tissues. Therefore, the correct arrangement is c) Bone, tendons, muscles, blood, liver, soft tissue, fat, lung.

setA.name: What color laser is typically used to stimulate the imaging plate in computed  radiography?
setA.hint: In computed radiography (CR), a red laser is typically used to stimulate the imaging plate. The red laser is chosen because it matches the peak sensitivity of the phosphor material, allowing for efficient and accurate stimulation of the imaging plate.

setA.name: The branch of radiology in which a chemical or compound containing a radioactive  isotope is called?
setA.hint: Nuclear Medicine is a specialized field of radiology that utilizes radioactive substances, known as radiopharmaceuticals, for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes.

setA.name: Montages refers to ___.
options: A pattern of electrodes on the head and the channels they are connected to
Asymmetrical electrodes placed on the forehead
The mathematical formula used to calculate EEG voltage differences
setA.hint: In the context of EEG, montages refer to the specific arrangement or combination of electrodes placed on the head and the channels to which they are conneected.

setA.name: What is the purpose of an ambulatory monitoring system in healthcare?
options: To monitor patients in critical care units
To monitor patient vital signs during surgeries
To monitor patients who are able to walk and move around
To monitor patients who are under anesthesia
setA.hint: The purpose of an ambulatory monitoring system in healthcare is to continuously monitor and record a patient's physiological parameters and activities while they go about their daily routines outside of a healthcare facility. This type of monitoring system allows healthcare providers to gather valuable information about the patient's health status over an extended period, beyond the limited time of a conventional clinical visit.

setA.name: What components are typically included in a wireless biotelemetry system?
options: Sensors, transmitters, a radio antenna, and a receiver
Sensors, transmitters, a wire connection, and a receiver
Sensors, transmitters, a camera, and a receiver
Sensors, transmitters, a satellite dish, and a receiver
setA.hint: If you look closely, the only variable in the given options is the 3rd one. The radio antenna is used to transmit and receive the radiofrequency signals between the transmitter and the receiver. It helps ensure reliable communication by sending and receiving the wireless signals.

setA.name: Which of the following instrument is most commonly used for measurement of blood  flow?
setA.hint: The most commonly used instrument for the measurement of blood flow is of the electromagnetic type. With this type of instrument, blood flow can be measured in intact blood vessels without  cannulation and under conditions which would otherwise be impossible.

setA.name: Modern day colorimeters and spectrophotmetry instruments use ___ light source.
setA.hint: Out of the given options Tungesten-halogen lamp is the most appropriate answer.

setA.name: Which threshold of hearing is measured by a pure-tone audiometer?
options: speech reception thresholds for diagnostic purposes
air-conduction and bone-conduction thresholds of hearing
setA.hint: Audiometers may be divided into two main groups on the basis of the type of stimulus they  provide to elicit auditory response: pure-tone audiometers and speech audiometers. A pure-tone  audiometer is used primarily to obtain both air-conduction and bone-conduction thresholds of hearing. Speech  audiometers are normally used to determine speech reception thresholds for diagnostic purposes  and to assess and evaluate the performance of hearing aids.

setA.name: Which wave from ECG waveforms becomes widened when the self-triggering impulse  does not arrive through the AV node?
setA.hint: When the self-triggering impulse does not arrive through the AV node, it can lead to an abnormal conduction pathway within the ventricles. This abnormal conduction can result in a widened QRS complex on the ECG waveform. The P wave represents atrial depolarization, the ST wave represents the period between ventricular depolarization and repolarization, and the T wave represents ventricular repolarization. These waves are not directly affected by the conduction pathway through the AV node.

setA.name: What precaution is used in diathermy?
options: Patient is made to lie on a soft pillow
Pads are used for grounding and completing the circuit
Patient is made to drink a large number of fluids
Wooden blocks are used for grounding
setA.hint: Pads or electrodes are used for grounding and completing the circuit in diathermy. These pads are typically placed on the patient's body at specific locations depending on the treatment area. The grounding pads help to ensure that the electrical current flows properly through the tissues being treated, minimizing the risk of electrical shocks or burns.

setA.name: The types of therapeutic diathermy machines that exist are ___.
options: Cold compress, microwave, and electrical impulse
setA.hint: a) Short wave, microwave, and ultrasound: These are the three main types of therapeutic diathermy machines.

setA.name: Hemodialysis machine works on the principle of ___.
setA.hint: Diffusion is the process by which solutes (waste products, toxins, and electrolytes) move from an area of higher concentration (blood) to an area of lower concentration (dialysate) across a semipermeable membrane. Ultrafiltration is the process of removing excess fluid from the blood. In hemodialysis, ultrafiltration is achieved by applying a pressure gradient across the semipermeable membrane. Therefore, the correct answer is a) Diffusion and ultrafiltration.

setA.name: The type of ventilation that enables the patient to breathe on his or her own, at his or her  respiratory rate, and with his or her depth between ventilator breaths is ___.
setA.hint: In SIMV, the ventilator delivers mandatory breaths at set intervals or on a fixed schedule to ensure the minimum required ventilation. However, it also allows the patient to breathe spontaneously between these mandatory breaths.

setA.name: Which is the “Can’t Let Go” range of current flow?
setA.hint: The "Can't Let Go" range of current flow typically refers to the range of current that can cause a person to experience muscle paralysis or the inability to voluntarily release their grip or let go of an object in an electrical shock scenario. The correct answer is c) 9-25 mA. This range is based on the fact that electrical currents in this range can cause muscle contractions, making it difficult or impossible for a person to let go of an electrified object. The exact values may vary depending on factors such as the individual's physiological characteristics and the path of current flow.

setA.name: The (Id - Vgs) characteristics of a MOSFET in the saturation region is ___.
setA.hint: The (Id - Vgs) characteristics of a MOSFET in the saturation region is quadratic in nature. The (Id - Vgs) characteristics plot the drain current (Id) as a function of the gate-source voltage (Vgs) while keeping the drain-source voltage (Vds) constant. The drain current increases with an increasing Vgs, but the rate of increase slows down as Vgs increases further. The quadratic relationship in the saturation region is due to the channel becoming pinch-off and the MOSFET reaching its maximum current-carrying capacity.

setA.name: In a differentiator circuit, a capacitor is placed in ___.
setA.hint: In an op-amp differentiator circuit, a capacitor is connected to the (negative) input.

setA.name: In a three phase AC circuit, the sum of all three generated voltages is ___.
setA.hint: In a three-phase AC circuit, the sum of all three generated voltages is zero. This is due to the nature of the three-phase system, where the voltages are 120 degrees out of phase with each other. As a result, the vector sum of the three voltages at any given instant is equal to zero.

setA.name: Peak reverse voltage of bridge rectifier for input signal of peak value Vm is ___.
setA.hint: In a bridge rectifier circuit, the input voltage is applied across the bridge, and the diodes conduct in alternating pairs to convert the AC input into a pulsating DC output. During the negative half-cycle of the input signal, the diodes conduct in reverse bias, and the voltage across each diode is equal to the peak value of the input signal. Since there are two diodes in series in the bridge rectifier, the peak reverse voltage across each diode is Vm. Therefore, the total peak reverse voltage across the bridge rectifier is 2Vm.

setA.name: A sudden increase in the total current into a parallel circuit may indicate ___.
options: Either a drop in source voltage or an open resistor
setA.hint: In a parallel circuit, each branch provides a separate path for current flow. If one of the resistors in a parallel circuit becomes open (i.e., has a break or high resistance), it effectively disconnects from the circuit. This causes the total resistance of the circuit to decrease, resulting in an increase in the total current flowing through the remaining branches. Although, an increase in source voltage will also cause a similar behaviour it is not just specific to parallel circuits.

setA.name: A good voltage regulation of a transformer means ___.
options: Output voltage fluctuation from no load to full load is least
Output voltage fluctuation with power factor is least
Difference between primary and secondary voltage is least
Difference between primary and secondary voltage is maximum
setA.hint: Voltage regulation refers to the ability of a transformer to maintain a relatively constant output voltage even when there are changes in the load. A transformer with good voltage regulation will exhibit minimal fluctuations in the output voltage when transitioning from no load to full load conditions. A transformer's voltage regulation is typically expressed as a percentage and is calculated using the formula: Voltage Regulation = ((V_no-load - V_full-load) / V_full-load) * 100%.

setA.name: For multi-input XNOR gate, the output is Logic High when the total number of Logic  High in the inputs signals is ___.
setA.hint: The XNOR gate performs an equality comparison on its input signals. It produces a Logic High output when an even number of the input signals are at Logic High (1) state. If an odd number of input signals are at Logic High state, the output of the XNOR gate will be Logic Low (0). Therefore, the output of a multi-input XNOR gate is Logic High when the total number of Logic High signals in the inputs is even.

setA.name: A full binary subtractor has ___ input lines and ___ output lines.
setA.hint: The three input lines of a full binary subtractor are: (i) Minuend, (ii) Subtrahend, (iii) Borrow-in and the two output lines are: (i) Difference and (ii) Borrow Out.

setA.name: A 10-bit SISO mode needs ___ clock pulses to load an 10-bit number into a register.
setA.hint: In a SISO mode, each bit of the input number is serially shifted into the register one at a time. For each clock pulse, one bit is shifted into the register until all 10 bits are loaded. Since we have a 10-bit number, it will take 10 clock pulses to load all 10 bits into the register in a SISO mode. Each clock pulse will shift one bit into the register until the entire 10-bit number is loaded.

setA.name: Which of the following statement is true regarding PAL (Programmable Array Logic)?
options: Once a PAL has been programmed it cannot be reprogrammed.
Its outputs are only active HIGHs
Its outputs are only active LOWs
setA.hint: Once a PAL has been programmed with a specific configuration, the programming is permanent and cannot be changed.

setA.name: The BCD number 1010111 has ___ priority.
setA.hint: To determine the priority of a BCD (Binary-Coded Decimal) number, we consider the value of the least significant digit (rightmost digit). In binary even numbers end with a 0, and odd numbers end with 1. For example, (even numbers) 0d = 0b, 2d = 10b, 4d = 100b; (and odd numbers) ( 1d = 1b, 3d = 11b, 5d = 101b).

setA.name: The centre frequency of a bandpass filter is always equal to ___.
options: Geometric average of the cut-off frequencies
setA.hint: I found a very long and thorough explanation here. TL;DR the geometric mean, ωc, of ωl and ωu, is defined when: ωuωc=ωcωl, or ωc2=ωlωu=1/LC=ωr2. Hence ωc=ωr. That is, the geometric mean of the corner frequencies is the resonant frequency.

setA.name: Laplace transform of a step function is ___.
setA.hint: A unit step function is 0 fot t < 0 and 1 for t>=0 .L{step(t)} = ∫[0 to ∞] e^(-st) dt

setA.name: A block of mass 10 kg is attached to a spring of stiffness 360 N/m. A velocity of 6 m/s is  given to the mass when the spring is in unstretched condition. The block will come to  rest after moving a distance of ___.
setA.hint: To determine the distance the block will move before coming to rest, we can use the principles of energy conservation. The initial kinetic energy of the block is given by (1/2)mv^2, where m is the mass of the block and v is its initial velocity. The potential energy stored in the spring when it is stretched by a distance x is given by (1/2)kx^2, where k is the spring constant and x is the displacement. Initially, the block has only kinetic energy, and as it comes to rest, all the initial kinetic energy will be converted into potential energy stored in the spring. Therefore, we can equate the initial kinetic energy to the potential energy at maximum displacement. (1/2)mv^2 = (1/2)kx^2. Plug in m = 10 kg, v = 6 m/s and k = 360 N/m to get x.

setA.name: For a type-I system, the intersection of the initial slope of the bode plot with 0 dB axis  gives ___.
setA.hint: The intersection of the initial slope of the Bode plot with the 0 dB axis occurs at the low-frequency region, where the gain of the system is still increasing. This point corresponds to the steady-state response of the system. By measuring the distance between this intersection point and the 0 dB axis, you can determine the value of the error constant. Therefore, the correct answer is Error constant.

setA.name: Role of the transmitter in the communication system is to ___.
options: Decode a signal to be transmitted
Convert one form of energy into other
Detect and amplify information signal from the carrier
Produce radio waves to transmit data
setA.hint: The role of the transmitter in a communication system is to generate and emit electromagnetic signals, such as radio waves, that carry the encoded or modulated information to be transmitted.

setA.name: Carrier swing is defined as ___.
options: Total variation in frequency from the lowest to the highest point
Frequency deviation above or below the carrier frequency
setA.hint: Carrier swing is defined as the maximum extent of variation or deviation in the amplitude or voltage level of the carrier signal in a modulated communication system. Therefore d) None of the above is the correct answer.

setA.name: A single tone 4 kHz message signal is sampled with 9 kHz, 7 kHz and 5 kHz. The  aliasing effect will be seen in the reconstructed signal when the signal is sampled with ___.
options: any of 9 kHz, 7 kHz, or 5 kHz
setA.hint: The 4 kHz message signal is sampled with 9 kHz, 7 kHz, and 5 kHz. To avoid aliasing, the sampling frequency should be at least 8 kHz (twice the maximum frequency of the message signal). Therefore, the aliasing effect will be seen in the reconstructed signal when the signal is sampled with a frequency lower than 8 kHz. Therefore, d) both 7 kHz and 5 kHz is the correct answer.

setA.name: Standard dimensions (mm x mm) of A3 drawing sheet is ___.
setA.hint: The standard dimensions of an drawing sheet is usually measured in (mm), and A3 sheets have a dimensions of 297 mm x 420 mm.

setA.name: Which of the following methods of charging depreciation of an asset has increased  amount of depreciation as the age of asset increases?
setA.hint: The method of charging depreciation that has an increased amount of depreciation as the age of the asset increases is the "Diminishing Balance Method" or "Declining Balance Method".

setA.name: The process of optimizing the project’s limited resources without extending the project  duration is known as ___.
setA.hint: The process of optimizing the project’s limited resources without extending the project  duration is known as   "Resource Level".

setA.name: The process of composing/raising the required fund from different sources such as  equity, preferred stock, bond and debenture is known as ___.
setA.hint: The correct answer is "a) Capital structure planning." Capital structure planning involves determining the appropriate mix of equity, preferred stock, bonds, and debentures to raise funds for a project or business. It aims to find the optimal balance between different sources of capital to support the financial needs of the organization.

setA.name: In which of the following society, people used to seek their existence on growing plants  for their cattle and domestic animals?
setA.hint: In agricultural societies, people primarily rely on the cultivation of crops and the raising of livestock for their sustenance and survival. Agriculture forms the basis of their economy and provides food, materials, and resources for their daily needs. These societies typically have a close connection to the land, engage in farming practices, and have a significant dependence on agricultural activities for their livelihood.

setA.name: According to Nepal Engineering Council Act, 2055 (Revised, 2079), all engineering  academic institutions shall be ___ in the Council.
setA.hint: According to the Nepal Engineering Council Act, 2055 (Revised, 2079), all engineering academic institutions shall be "recognized" by the Council.

setB.name: In the motor end plate, all the following are TRUE EXCEPT ___.
options: The acetylcholine receptors are similar to those in smooth muscle.
Lack of Ca diminishes the release of acetylcholine
There is a high concentration of the cholinesterase enzyme
There is a delay of neuromuscular transmission of 0.5 millisecond
setB.hint: The statement "There is a delay of neuromuscular transmission of 0.5 millisecond" is NOT true for the motor end plate. In the motor end plate, the neuromuscular transmission is very rapid, with a delay of only a few microseconds

setB.name: Which of the following statements describe endothelial cells the most accurately?
options: Flat, polygonal, elongated in the direction of blood flow
Irregular, prone to overlap with other endothelial cells
setB.hint: Endothelial cells are typically flat and form a single layer lining the interior surface of blood vessels. They often have a polygonal shape and are elongated in the direction of blood flow, which allows for the smooth passage of blood through the vessels.

setB.name: A patient is scheduled to have a chronic abscess incised and drained. What would you  expect a microscopic examination of the contents of the abscess to most likely show?
options: An acute inflammatory infiltrate of PMNs
setB.hint: As sated in option a), while macrophages may be present in the chronic abscess, they are not the only cell type expected to be seen. Similarly, b) while necrotic tissue may be present in abscesses, it is also not a defining characteristic. d) PMNs (polymorphonuclear leukocytes or neutrophils) are predominantly associated with acute inflammation. In a chronic abscess, there is typically a mixture of inflammatory cells present. Neutrophils are often seen as they are involved in the initial acute inflammatory response. However, as the abscess progresses and becomes chronic, other types of inflammatory cells start to appear, such as lymphocytes and plasma cells. This leaves us with "c) Neutrophils, lymphocytes, & plasma cells" as the correct answer.

setB.name: Which of the following is the appropriate option?
options: 1. Differentiated Stem Cells; 2. Biomaterials; 3. Growth Factors; 4. Autologous
1. Autologous; 2. Differentiated Stem Cells; 3. Biomaterials; 4. Growth Factors
1. Autologous; 2. Differentiated Stem Cells; 3. Growth Factors; 4. Biomaterials
1. Autologous; 2. Growth Factors; 3. Differentiated Stem Cells; 1. Autologous
setB.hint: The appropriate option in the context of tissue engineering, involving cells, signals, and biomaterials, would be: "c) 1. Autologous; 2. Differentiated Stem Cells; 3. Growth Factors; 4. Biomaterials." based on the order of importance or preference.

setB.name: What is the role of stem cells with regard to the function of adult tissues and organs?
options: Stem cells are undifferentiated cells that divide asymmetrically, giving rise to one  daughter that remains a stem cell and one daughter that will differentiate to replace  damaged and worn-out cells in the adult tissue or organ.
Stem cells are embryonic cells that persist in the adult, and can give rise to all of the  cell types in the body.
Stem cells are embryonic cells that persist in the adult, and can give rise to all of the  cell types in the body.
Stem cells are differentiated cells that have yet to express the genes and proteins  characteristic of their differentiated state, and do so when needed for repair of tissues  and organs.
setB.hint: The most accurate statement regarding the role of stem cells in the function of adult tissues and organs is: " a) Stem cells are undifferentiated cells that divide asymmetrically, giving rise to one daughter that remains a stem cell and one daughter that will differentiate to replace damaged and worn-out cells in the adult tissue or organ." This statement accurately describes the characteristic behavior of stem cells. Stem cells have the ability to divide and produce two different daughter cells through asymmetric division. One daughter cell remains a stem cell, maintaining the stem cell population, while the other daughter cell undergoes differentiation to replace damaged or worn-out cells within adult tissues and organs.

setB.name: What is the difference between a pacemaker and the total artificial heart (TAH)?
options: A pacemaker is smaller in size and completely embedded in the body as compared to  TAH in which some system lies outside the body
A pacemaker replaces only the ventricles but a TAH replaces the whole heart
A pacemaker is an assistive device which helps the original heart to generate impulses  but a TAH completely replaces the heart
A pacemaker is made out of organic polymers while the TAH is metallic
setB.hint: A pacemaker monitors the heart's electrical activity and delivers electrical impulses when needed to regulate the heart rate and rhythm. It does not replace the pumping function of the heart. A TAH, on the other hand, completely replaces the native heart's pumping function by mechanically pumping blood throughout the body. It mimics the natural circulation of blood and supports the patient until a suitable donor heart becomes available for transplantation.

setB.name: A 20-year-old man visits his doctor, worried about his worsening diarrhea, abdominal  pain and blood in his stool. The doctor wonders if he may have an inflammatory bowel  disease. Which kind of diagnostic imaging technology should the doctor use first to test  his theory?
options: Positron Emission Tomography (PET) scan of his abdominal area
MRI three-dimensional reconstruction of his colon
setB.hint: Colonoscopy is the primary diagnostic imaging technology used to evaluate the colon and rectum for inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD) such as Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. It involves the insertion of a flexible tube with a camera into the colon to examine the lining of the gastrointestinal tract. With colonoscopy, the doctor can directly visualize the mucosal lining, identify any inflammation, ulcers, or abnormal tissue, and even take biopsies for further analysis.

setB.name: What type of imaging modalities are shown in the following picture?
setB.hint: The images in the first, second and third rows  in the above picture include T1, DTI and fMRI images respectively.

setB.name: Which of the following statement is true?
options: Impedance pneumography is an indirect technique of measurement which measures  rate through relation between respiratory depth and thoracic impedance change
Impedance pneumography is a direct technique of measurement which measures rate  through difference in temperature between inspired and expired air
Thermistor method is an indirect technique of measurement which measures rate  through difference in temperature between inspired and expired air
Thermistor method is a direct technique of measurement which measures rate through  relation between respiratory depth and thoracic impedance change
setB.hint: Impedance pneumography is an indirect technique for the measurement of respiration rate. Using externally applied  electrodes on the thorax, the impedance pneumograph measures rate through the relationship between respiratory depth and thoracic impedance change.

setB.name: Which type of lead in the figure below along with its waveform denotes?
setB.hint: In bipolar configuration of ECG, Lead I: The positive electrode is placed on the left arm, and the negative electrode (also known as the reference electrode) is placed on the right arm. Lead II: The positive electrode is placed on the left leg, and the negative electrode is placed on the right arm. Lead III: The positive electrode is placed on the left leg, and the negative electrode is placed on the left arm.

setB.name: The proper placement of an AED (automated external defibrillator) is ___.
options: One pad on upper right side of the chest, and the other on lower left side of the chest.
One pad on lower right side of the chest, and the other on upper left side of the chest
One pad on lower right side of the chest, and the other on lower left side of the chest.
One pad on upper right side of the chest, and the other on upper left side of the chest.
setB.hint: a) One pad on the upper right side of the chest, and the other on the lower left side of the chest. The placement of the pads may vary slightly depending on the specific AED model and manufacturer's instructions. However, in most cases, the upper right and lower left side of the chest are the recommended positions for pad placement to optimize the flow of electrical current through the heart.

setB.name: Which statement is true?
options: With positive-pressure ventilation (PPV), the transpulmonary pressure is increased by  making the alveolar pressure more positive; in contrast, with negative-pressure  ventilation (NPV), the transpulmonary pressure is increased by making the pleural  pressure more negative

With positive-pressure ventilation (PPV), the transpulmonary pressure is decreased by  making the alveolar pressure more negative; in contrast, with negative-pressure ventilation (NPV), the transpulmonary pressure is increased by making the pleural  pressure more negative

With positive-pressure ventilation (PPV), the transpulmonary pressure is increased by  making the alveolar pressure more positive; in contrast, with negative-pressure  ventilation (NPV), the transpulmonary pressure is decreased by making the pleural  pressure more positive

With positive-pressure ventilation (PPV), the transpulmonary pressure is increased by  making the alveolar pressure more negative; in contrast, with negative-pressure  ventilation (NPV), the transpulmonary pressure is increased by making the pleural  pressure more positive

setB.name: A Norton circuit with 10 A current source and 15 Ω resistance is connected across a  resistance of 5 Ω. The current in 5 Ω resistance will be ___.
setB.hint: Given: Norton current (In) = 10 A Norton resistance (Rn) = 15 Ω Resistance across which current is to be found = 5 Ω. We can calculate the total current flowing through the 5 Ω resistance using Ohm's Law: Total current (I) = In * (Rn / (Rn + 5 Ω)).

setB.name: In a non-inverting op-amp based amplifier, Rf =10K and R1 = 1K. If Vin is sine wave  with 10 mv amplitude and 100 Hz frequency. The output wave form will be ___.
setB.hint: To determine the output waveform of a non-inverting op-amp amplifier, we can use the voltage gain equation: Voltage gain (Av) = 1 + (Rf / R1). After we obtain Av, we can multiply it with Vin to get Vout; Vout = Vin * Av. Since the input voltage is a sine wave with, the output waveform will also be a sine wave with the same frequency but amplified the voltage gain.

setB.name: How many 3 × 8 line decoders with an enable input line are needed to construct a 6 × 64  line decoder without using any other logic gate?
setB.hint: Since each 3 × 8 line decoder provides 8 output liness, we will need a total of 8 decoders to cover 64 outputs (8 * 8 = 64). Additionally, you need one more decoder to provide the enable signal. Hence, the total number of 3 × 8 line decoders required is 8 + 1 = 9.

setB.name: Which of the following Boolean algebraic expressions is incorrect?
setB.hint: The expression "d) (A + B')(A + B)= A" is incorrect because it violates the complement law in Boolean algebra. The complement law states that A + A' = 1, which means that if a variable A is summed with its complement A', the result is always 1. In the given expression, (A + B')(A + B), if we substitute A = 0 and B = 1, we get (0 + 1')(0 + 1) = (1)(1) = 1, which does not equal A = 0. Therefore, the expression is incorrect.

setB.name: Find the function f(t) for the following function F(s): F(s) = 1/ [s(s+1)(s+5)]
setB.hint: Use partial fraction decomposition and perform inverse Laplace transform.

setB.name: What will be the bandwidth occupied by a DSB signal when the modulating frequency  lies in the range from 100 Hz to 10KHz.
setB.hint: BW = 2 * Fm ; where Fm = Fmax - Fmin.

setB.name: Effective monthly interest rate will be ___, if nominal interest rate of 10% accounted for continuous compounding.

setB.namehtml:
By considering following activities of a project, the project duration will be ___.
ActivityABCDE
Immediate predecessors---CA, B, D
Duration (days)45375
